 I support gay rights, have a ton of gay friends, when I was tattooing I would say 80% of my clientele was gay. My son has been raised around gay people and has no problems with anyone. We are a very eclectic family :)

BobNelson2

How do you feel about this. 

 
 I have to confess that in a way, it makes me sort of sad. I was a speaker for a similar round of discussions in high schools in the community around my university some (gasp!) 25+ years ago. Regardless of how far we've come in less than three decades, it's still a bit dispiriting that this is still necessary.
 
 These days, I'm sure that there's much less of the wide-eyed wonder at the actual presence of a h-o-m-o-s-e-x-u-a-l on the face of some of the kids. There was a zoo-exhibit-like aspect to our visit. On the other hand, I'm sure there are still a couple kids sitting there with eyes wide in terror and fear. 
 
 I remember one kid in one class. Still breaks my heart. He was so scared and so sad.

 Ok, hold on here a second, don't get your briefs in a bunch just yet. As a fifteen year old you are by nature going to be headstrong. I understand that. 
 But please don't get so upset. Remember, I am gay.
 
 
 
 If they are teaching kids about gay people, what better way than to introduce them to one. I'm sorry but a parent doesn't get to dictate what their child is exposed to once they are put in public school or any non-home school situation.

 
 
 Nope, that's where you are wrong. 
 Parents are notified about other school activities because it is definitely up to the parent as to what a child is exposed to. 
 Public school does NOT mean a school has free reign as to what it puts into its curriculum. Pubic schools are funded by tax dollars, voted on by citizens of the area in question and mandated by the feds, states, counties and town where the schools reside. 
 Curriculums are indeed a parents perogative to know.
 
 
 One of the main points in schools are to get the children ready socially for the world as well, and since this includes gay people that only makes since. I may have a problem if he was actually trying to convince the children that they should be gay or that they were somehow inferior to others, but I doubt that's the case.

 
 I doubt it too, but not all parents would feel that way. Some have very strong sentiments about sexuality. Not just sex, per se, but the idea of sexuality. Do not confuse the two.
 
 
 If a Christian came in to talk about religion in a religious studies class would you be outraged?

 
 I think the question here is what was a religious studies class doing in a Public School setting to begin with? 
 
 Health class is about personal health. Yes, sexual health is most definitely a part of that, but sexuality is not. That really moreover belongs in a sociology class setting. 
 
 
 As long as they talked in an informative tone and not "we're right because..." than that's fine with me, and that's coming from an atheist.

 
 
 Again, I agree. No, if a Christian came in to talk to a "religions" class I wouldn't have a problem with it. I would however have a problem with religious studies classes being taught in a public school. I don't feel they belong there. 
 As far as people who were clearly identified as Gay, Lesbian and Bisexual coming to speak to a health class I feel is out of context. 
 Sure there are health issues which uniquely impact gays/lesbians and bisexuals, but to bring in speakers who are identified as such draws the wrong conclussions. 
 One does not need to be gay to understand gay health issues. Nor does a person speaking on gay health issues need to be identified as being gay. It shouldn't matter who or how the speaker identifies him/herself. As long as the information given is accurate and unbiased the speakers gender, sexual identity, race, relgion, age or physical ability should not matter. 
 Again, it's moreover an issue of merit vs. status. 
 
 But, since the speakers were indeed identified as being gay, lesbian and bisexual, my question would be moreover what was the subject matter at hand? 
 If it was about being or identifying as gay, lesbian and bisexual I feel that it's more of a societal issue and would be better served in a sociology setting.
BobNelson2

Health class is about personal health. Yes, sexual health is most definitely a part of that, but sexuality is not. That really moreover belongs in a sociology class setting. 

 
 How in the world could one teach a course about sexual health and biology without mentioning sexual orientation?
 
 Discussion of gay people belongs in schools not because it's "the right thing to do", not because "it promotes tolerance", but because it's REALITY. Schools, first and foremost, are there to teach about the world.
 
 For the same reason, it would be entirely appropriate for a school to have a religious studies course. Not to study ONE religion, but to study religion and it's influence on world history, etc. Of course, it would probably be an elective. Mandatory history and literature courses (if they still require those at all) should address religion in the context of the subject matter. They should probably also address homosexuality, at least in the context of the many historical figures who were homosexual.

 I don't know which class it should be taught in. Basically our 10th grade health class covered most topics they weren't allowed to cover until then by law.  As crazy as it may seem, I actually find myself agreeing with you here. 
 As far as incestuous relationships there are indeed certain health issues which are unique to those types of relationships. Mainly birth defects. 
 The same does not completely hold true for polygamous relationships, because even though they are polygamous those involved are still monogamous to their partners. Polygamous does not equal promiscuous. They just aren't the same. 
 STD's and birth defects of issue to incest and promiscuity aren't of issue in committed polygamous or monogamous relationships regardless of gender.
